title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: Authors: Lucy Dâ€™Agostino McGowanLicense: MIT

title: Tipping Point Analyses
code: # install.packages(devtools) devtools::install_github("lucymcgowan/tipr") library("tipr")

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: fitting model, can determine unmeasured confounder needed tip analysis. unmeasured confounder determined two quantities, association exposure unmeasured confounder (unmeasured confounder continuous, indicated smd, binary, exposed_p unexposed_p), association unmeasured confounder outcome outcome_association. Using ðŸ“¦, can fix one solve . Alternatively, can fix solve n, , many unmeasured confounders magnitude tip analysis. example, model fit exposure-outcome relationship 1.5 (95% CI: 1.2, 1.8).

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: interested continuous unmeasured confounder, use tip_with_continuous() function. Letâ€™s assume relationship unmeasured confounder outcome 1.5 (outcome_association = 1.5), letâ€™s solve association exposure unmeasured confounder needed tip analysis (case, solving smd, mean difference needed exposed unexposed). hypothetical unobserved continuous confounder association 1.5 outcome need scaled mean difference exposure groups 0.45 tip analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip(1.2, outcome_association = 1.5) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.45 ##   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.5  ## # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 ##   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ ##             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2 0.450                 1.5                    1

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: Now interested binary unmeasured confounder, use tip_with_binary() function. Letâ€™s assume unmeasured confounder prevalent 25% exposed population (exposed_p = 0.25) 10% unexposed population (unexposed_p = 0.10) â€“ letâ€™s solve association unmeasured confounder outcome needed tip analysis (outcome_association). hypothetical unobserved binary confounder prevalent 10% unexposed population 25% exposed population need association outcome 2.5 tip analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip_with_binary(1.2, exposed_p = 0.25, unexposed_p = 0.10) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 0.25 ##   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0.1 ##   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.54  ## # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6 ##   adjusted_effect observed_effect exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association ##             <dbl>           <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2      0.25         0.1                2.54 ## # â€¦ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: Suppose concerned many small, independent, continuous, unmeasured confounders present. take 15 independent unmeasured confounders scaled mean difference exposure groups 0.25 association outcome 1.05 tip observed analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip(1.2, smd = 0.25, outcome_association = 1.05) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 15 unmeasured confounders ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.25 ##   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.05  ## # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 ##   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ ##             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2  0.25                1.05                 14.9

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: functions created easily integrate models tidied using broom package. necessary use functions, nice feature choose . example logistic regression fit glm tidied tidy function broom can directly fed tip() function.
code: if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&  requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%     broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%     dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%     dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%     tip(outcome_association = 2.5) } ## The observed effect (1.13) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.13 ##   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.5  ## # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 ##   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ ##             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> ## 1               1            1.13 0.133                 2.5                    1

title:
Adjust an observed regression coefficient for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_coef
text: effect Numeric. Observed exposure - outcome effect regression model. can beta coefficient, lower confidence bound beta coefficient, upper confidence bound beta coefficient. smd Numeric. Estimated difference scaled means unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed population outcome_association Numeric. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE

title:
Adjust an observed regression coefficient for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_coef
text: Data frame.

title:
Adjust an observed regression coefficient for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_coef
code: ## Update an observed coefficient of 0.5 with an unmeasured confounder ## with a difference in scaled means between exposure groups of 0.2 ## and coefficient of 0.3 adjust_coef(0.5, 0.2, 0.3) #> The observed effect (0.5) is updated to 0.44 by a confounder with the following specifications: #> * estimated difference in scaled means: 0.2 #> * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.3 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed   smd outcome_association #>             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1            0.44             0.5   0.2                 0.3

Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder unexposed population outcome_association Numeric. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE

code: adjust_coef_with_binary(1.1, 0.5, 0.3, 1.3) #> The observed effect (1.1) is updated to 0.84 by an confounder with the following specifications: #> * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 0.5 #> * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0.3 #> * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.3 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>             <dbl>           <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1           0.840             1.1       0.5         0.3                 1.3

title:
Adjust a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” adjust_coef_with_r2
code: adjust_coef_with_r2(   effect,   se,   df,   exposure_r2,   outcome_r2,   verbose = TRUE,   alpha = 0.05,   ... )

title:
Adjust a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” adjust_coef_with_r2
text: effect Numeric. Observed exposure - outcome effect regression model. point estimate (beta coefficient) se Numeric. Standard error effect previous parameter. df Numeric positive value. Residual degrees freedom model used estimate observed exposure - outcome effect. total number observations minus number parameters estimated model. Often models estimated intercept N - k - 1 k number predictors model. exposure_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder exposure given measured covariates. outcome_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder outcome given exposure measured covariates. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE alpha Significance level. Default = 0.05. ... Optional arguments passed sensemakr::adjusted_estimate() function.

title:
Adjust a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” adjust_coef_with_r2
text: data frame.

title:
Adjust a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” adjust_coef_with_r2
text: Carlos Cinelli, Jeremy Ferwerda Chad Hazlett (2021). sensemakr: Sensitivity Analysis Tools Regression Models. R package version 0.1.4. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=sensemakr

title:
Adjust a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” adjust_coef_with_r2
code: adjust_coef_with_r2(0.5, 0.1, 102, 0.05, 0.1) #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 10 #>   effect_adjusted lb_adjusted ub_adjusted effect_observed lb_observed #>             <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>           <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1           0.427       0.233       0.621             0.5       0.302 #> # â€¦ with 5 more variables: ub_observed <dbl>, se_observed <dbl>, #> #   df_observed <dbl>, exposure_r2 <dbl>, outcome_r2 <dbl>

what:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
title:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
text: Adjust observed hazard ratio normally distributed confounder

title:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
code: adjust_hr(   effect,   smd,   outcome_association,   verbose = TRUE,   hr_correction = FALSE )  adjust_hr_with_continuous(   effect,   smd,   outcome_association,   verbose = TRUE,   hr_correction = FALSE )

title:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
text: effect Numeric positive value. Observed exposure - outcome hazard ratio. can point estimate, lower confidence bound, upper confidence bound. smd Numeric. Estimated difference scaled means unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed population outcome_association Numeric. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE hr_correction Logical. Indicates whether use correction factor. methods used function based relative risks. rare outcomes, hazard ratio approximates relative risk. common outcomes, correction factor needed. common outcome (>15%), set TRUE. Default: FALSE.

title:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
text: Data frame.

title:
Adjust an observed hazard ratio for a normally distributed
confounder â€” adjust_hr
code: adjust_hr(0.9, -0.9, 1.3) #> The observed effect (HR: 0.9) is updated to HR: 1.14 by a confounder with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means: -0.9 #>   * estimated association (HR) between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.3 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4 #>   hr_adjusted hr_observed   smd outcome_association #>         <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1        1.14         0.9  -0.9                 1.3

Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE hr_correction Logical. Indicates whether use correction factor. methods used function based relative risks. rare outcomes, hazard ratio approximates relative risk. common outcomes, correction factor needed. common outcome (>15%), set TRUE. Default: FALSE.

title: Adjust an observed odds ratio with a binary confounder â€” adjust_or_with_binary
text: effect Numeric positive value. Observed exposure - outcome odds ratio. can point estimate, lower confidence bound, upper confidence bound. exposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE or_correction Logical. Indicates whether use correction factor. methods used function based relative risks. rare outcomes, odds ratio approximates relative risk. common outcomes, correction factor needed. common outcome (>15%), set TRUE. Default: FALSE.

title: Adjust an observed odds ratio with a binary confounder â€” adjust_or_with_binary
text: Data frame.

title: Adjust an observed odds ratio with a binary confounder â€” adjust_or_with_binary
code: adjust_or_with_binary(3, 1, 0, 3) #> The observed effect (OR: 3) is updated to OR: 1 by an confounder with the following specifications: #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 1 #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 3 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   or_adjusted or_observed exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>         <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1           1           3         1           0                   3 adjust_or_with_binary(3, 1, 0, 3, or_correction = TRUE) #> The observed effect (RR: 1.73) is updated to RR: 1 by an confounder with the following specifications: #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 1 #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.73 #> You opted to use the odds ratio correction to convert your odds ratios to approximate risk ratios. #> This is a good idea if the outcome is common (>15%). #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   rr_adjusted rr_observed exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>         <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1           1        1.73         1           0                1.73

code: observed_bias_tbl(ps_mod, outcome_mod, drop_list = NULL)

title: Create a data frame to assist with creating an observed bias plot â€” observed_bias_tbl
text: ps_mod Model object propensity score model outcome_mod Model object outcome model drop_list Named list covariates groups covariates drop NULL, default dropping covariate one time.

title: Create a data frame to assist with creating an observed bias plot â€” observed_bias_tbl
text: Data frame following columns: dropped: covariate group covariates dropped type: Explanation dropped, whether refers single covariate (covariate) group covariates (group) ps_formula: new formula updated propensity score model outcome_formula: new formula updated outcome model ps_model: new model object updated propensity score model p: updated propensity score

title: Create a data frame to assist with creating an observed bias plot â€” observed_bias_tbl
code: ps_mod <- glm(am ~ mpg + cyl + I(hp^2), data = mtcars) outcome_mod <- lm(qsec ~ am + hp + disp + wt, data = mtcars) observed_bias_tbl(  ps_mod,  outcome_mod,  drop_list = list(    group_one = c("mpg", "hp"),    group_two = c("cyl", "wt")    )  ) #> # A tibble: 2 Ã— 6 #>   dropped   type  ps_formula outcome_formula ps_model p          #>   <chr>     <chr> <list>     <list>          <list>   <list>     #> 1 group_one group <formula>  <formula>       <glm>    <dbl [32]> #> 2 group_two group <formula>  <formula>       <glm>    <dbl [32]>

text: tip Numeric. Value like tip . point_estimate Numeric. Result estimate full model. lb Numeric. Result lower bound full model. ub Numeric. Result upper bound full model. tip_desc Character. description tipping point.

title: Create a data frame to combine with an observed bias data frame demonstrating a hypothetical unmeasured confounder â€” observed_bias_tip
text: data frame five columns: dropped: input tip_desc type: Explanation dropped, tip clarify calculated tipping point. point_estimate: shifted point estimate lb: shifted lower bound ub: shifted upper bound

title: Robustness value â€” r_value
text: Numeric. Robustness value

title: Robustness value â€” r_value
text: Carlos Cinelli, Jeremy Ferwerda Chad Hazlett (2021). sensemakr: Sensitivity Analysis Tools Regression Models. R package version 0.1.4. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=sensemakr

title: Robustness value â€” r_value

what: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
text: choose one following, estimated: smd outcome_association

title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
code: tip(   effect,   smd = NULL,   outcome_association = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   correction_factor = "none" )  tip_with_continuous(   effect,   smd = NULL,   outcome_association = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   correction_factor = "none" )  tip_c(   effect,   smd = NULL,   outcome_association = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   correction_factor = "none" )

title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
text: effect Numeric positive value. Observed exposure - outcome effect (assumed exponentiated coefficient, relative risk, odds ratio, hazard ratio). can point estimate, lower confidence bound, upper confidence bound. smd Numeric. Estimated difference scaled means unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE correction_factor Character string. Options "none", "hr", "". common outcomes (>15%), odds ratio hazard ratio good estimate relative risk. cases, can apply correction factor. supplying hazard ratio common outcome, set "hr"; supplying odds ratio common outcome, set ""; supplying risk ratio outcome rare, set "none" (default).

title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
text: Data frame.

title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip
code: ## to estimate the association between an unmeasured confounder and outcome ## needed to tip analysis tip(1.2, smd = -2) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.91 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ #>             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2    -2               0.913                    1  ## to estimate the number of unmeasured confounders specified needed to tip ## the analysis tip(1.2, smd = -2, outcome_association = .99) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 9 unmeasured confounders #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.99 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ #>             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2    -2                0.99                 9.07  ## Example with broom if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%    broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%    dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%    tip(outcome_association = 2.5) } #> The observed effect (1.13) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.13 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.5 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confouâ€¦ #>             <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1               1            1.13 0.133                 2.5                    1

text: effect Numeric. Observed exposure - outcome effect regression model. can beta coefficient, lower confidence bound beta coefficient, upper confidence bound beta coefficient. smd Numeric. Estimated scaled mean difference unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE

title: Tip a linear model coefficient with a continuous confounder. â€” tip_coef
text: Data frame.

title: Tip a linear model coefficient with a continuous confounder. â€” tip_coef
code: ## to estimate the association between an unmeasured confounder and outcome ## needed to tip analysis tip_coef(1.2, smd = -2) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: -0.6 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4 #>   observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confounders #>             <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                    <dbl> #> 1             1.2    -2                -0.6                        1  ## to estimate the number of unmeasured confounders specified needed to tip ## the analysis tip_coef(1.2, smd = -2, outcome_association = -0.05) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 12 unmeasured confounders #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: -0.05 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4 #>   observed_effect   smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confounders #>             <dbl> <dbl>               <dbl>                    <dbl> #> 1             1.2    -2               -0.05                       12  ## Example with broom if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   lm(wt ~ mpg, data = mtcars) %>%    broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%    dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%    tip_coef(outcome_association = 2.5) } #> The observed effect (-0.17) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -0.07 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.5 #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4 #>   observed_effect     smd outcome_association n_unmeasured_confounders #>             <dbl>   <dbl>               <dbl>                    <dbl> #> 1          -0.171 -0.0684                 2.5                        1

title:
Tip a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” tip_coef_with_r2
text: effect Numeric. Observed exposure - outcome effect regression model. point estimate (beta coefficient) se Numeric. Standard error effect previous parameter. df Numeric positive value. Residual degrees freedom model used estimate observed exposure - outcome effect. total number observations minus number parameters estimated model. Often models estimated intercept N - k - 1 k number predictors model. exposure_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder exposure given measured covariates. outcome_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder outcome given exposure measured covariates. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE alpha Significance level. Default = 0.05. tip_bound want tip bound? Default = FALSE, tip point estimate ... Optional arguments passed sensemakr::adjusted_estimate() function.

title:
Tip a regression coefficient using the partial R2
for an unmeasured confounder-exposure relationship and unmeasured confounder-
outcome relationship â€” tip_coef_with_r2

code: tip_hr(   effect,   smd = NULL,   outcome_association = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   hr_correction = FALSE )  tip_hr_with_continuous(   effect,   smd = NULL,   outcome_association = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   hr_correction = FALSE )

title: Tip an observed hazard ratio with a normally distributed confounder. â€” tip_hr
text: effect Numeric positive value. Observed exposure - outcome hazard ratio. can point estimate, lower confidence bound, upper confidence bound. smd Numeric. Estimated difference scaled means unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE hr_correction Logical. Indicates whether use correction factor. methods used function based relative risks. rare outcomes, hazard ratio approximates relative risk. common outcomes, correction factor needed. common outcome (>15%), set TRUE. Default: FALSE.

text: effect Numeric positive value. Observed exposure - outcome hazard ratio. can point estimate, lower confidence bound, upper confidence bound. exposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed_p Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder unexposed population outcome_association Numeric positive value. Estimated association unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE hr_correction Logical. code: ## to estimate the association between an unmeasured confounder and outcome ## needed to tip analysis tip_with_binary(1.2, exposed_p = 0.5, unexposed_p = 0) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 0.5 #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.4 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>             <dbl>           <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2       0.5           0                 1.4 #> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>  ## to estimate the number of unmeasured confounders specified needed to tip ## the analysis tip_with_binary(1.2,   exposed_p = 0.5,   unexposed_p = 0,   outcome_association = 1.1) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 4 unmeasured confounders #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 0.5 #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.1 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>             <dbl>           <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2       0.5           0                 1.1 #> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>  ## Example with broom if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%    broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%    dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%    tip_with_binary(exposed_p = 1, outcome_association = 1.15) } #> The observed effect (1.13) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 1 #>   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0.12 #>   * estimated association between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.15 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6 #>   adjusted_effect observed_effect exposed_p unexposed_p outcome_association #>             <dbl>           <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1               1            1.13         1       0.119                1.15 #> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

title: tipr 0.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-05-05 Add additional functions specify *_with_continuous() (long form , function names, default unmeasured confounder Normally distributed) Change tip_lm() tip_coef().

title: tipr 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-04-16 Changed name lm_tip() tip_lm() API fundamentally updated functions now take numeric value first argument rather data frame. Added adjust_* functions allow specification unmeasured confounder qualities without tipping Split tip_* functions hazard ratio, odds ratio, relative risk Add R2 parameterization tip_coef_with_r2(), adjust_coef_with_r2(), r_value()

title: tipr 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-09-10 Added ability perform sensitivity analyses linear models via lm_tip()

title: tipr 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-16 Updated several function parameter names. main functions now tip() tip_with_binary(). parameter names self-explanatory. API fundamentally updated functions now take data frame first argument. now explicit (required) integration broom package.

title: tipr 0.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2017-11-28 initial CRAN release
